Measures: While use of non-sexual communication by groomers is extremely ambiguous, using a set of criteria - 'asking for hot picture', 'asking for alternate contact method', 'telling sexual preference' could be used to assess the prevalence of online grooming conversations on a platform.
Plus: Surprisingly predictive of online grooming (95%) without being based on complimentary language, another grooming mainstay
Minus: Requires access to conversations, technical to setup
References: Pranoto et al. 2015

Measures: Online grooming is not just a way to coerce children into offline meetups, but is itself a form of sexual exploitation. These acts, including: sharing porn sites with victims, streaming webcam material, sexting and the display of genitalia are not just preparation, but exploitation. An evaluative framework might include fields for these activities and use their frequency as measure of child sexual exploitation.
Plus: Understands 'digital' acts can be just as damaging as 'real world' exploitation
Minus: Highly personal information that participants may not want to disclose
References: Barber and Bettez 2014, 'Deconstructing the online grooming of youth'

Measures: Studies suggest that programmes that address CSEA may also contribute to more positive sexual health (later sexual debut, fewer partners, use of contraception). A programme might measure these broader sexual health behaviors as a proxy for lower vulnerability to grooming and sexual risk-taking online.
Plus: Holistic understanding of sexual health and sexual risk-taking
Minus: Broader indicator that may be loosely correlated to grooming specifically
References: UNFPA 2018, UNESCO 2015 'Emerging Evidence, Lessons and Practice in Comprehensive Sexuality Education: A Global Review'

Measures: Well-validated scale (compared with 16 earlier scales) that measure cyberbullying activities through 19 items that cover impersonation, social exclusion, shaming, insults, false accusations, coercion or intimidation.
References: Álvarez-García, D., Núñez, J. C., Barreiro-Collazo, A., & García, T. (2017). Validation of the Cybervictimization Questionnaire (CYVIC) for adolescents. Computers in Human Behavior, 70, 270-281.

Measures: A story generated by the child about the most significant change that resulted from the programme, collected through a digital form or input mechanism
Plus: Can synthesise complex data into a digestible form, with beginning / middle / end
Minus: Can obscure themes (evident in a thematic analysis); involves small number and potentially biased case studies
References: River of Life 2017

Measures:
Someone said nasty things to me or called me names using texts or online messages.
Someone spread rumors about me on the Internet.
Someone threatened me through texts or online messages.
Someone threatened me when I was playing an online game.
I was excluded or ignored by others when playing an online game.
Someone said nasty things to me or called me names when I was playing an online game.
Plus: Focuses on younger children (though a prior study examines the same scale for teenagers); validates European model.
Minus: May be less relevant in Asian context; stronger results for victims than perpetrators.
References: Williford, A., & DePaolis, K. J. (2019). Validation of a Cyber Bullying and Victimization Measure Among Elementary School-Aged Children. Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal, 36(5), 557-570.

Measures: Some studies suggest a link between pornography consumption and harmful or aggressive sexual behaviors. The consumption of porn (frequency, duration, etc) across a population might therefore function as a 'proxy' indicator for child sexual exploitation and the effectiveness of a programme.
Plus: Well understood issue that is heavily prevalent amongst teens
Minus: Proxy' indicator that must be combined with others, participants might not answer honestly
References: McKibbin, Humphreys, and Hamilton 2017 'Young people who sexually abused reflect on preventing harmful sexual behavior', Taylor 2018 'Pornography as a Public Health Issue'

Measures: number of calls to a hotline or helpline during a period, pre and post intervention
References: Keeping Children Safe Online

Measures: Adolescents often send erotic pictures impulsively on social networks. These can be used for coercive sexual advancement by peers and can also be circulated into pedophile networks, leading to victimization. These images can also be used for cyberbullying, generating humiliation amongst peers. Measuring and reducing this behavior could lead to less grooming and cyberbullying.
Plus: Seems a clear risk factor for both grooming and cyberbullying, so important to reduce
Minus: Requires either platform/tech surveillance (privacy invasive) or self-reporting measure and honest responses
References: Schoeps et al. 2020, 'Risk factor for being a victim of online grooming in adolescents'

Measures: Some forms of sexual exploitation take the form of meet-ups offline. One indicator would be asking whether children have met certain adults in this capacity, or would be willing to do so, and could be coupled to an awareness raising campaign.
Plus: An offline meetup of this nature is a clear indicator of child sexual exploitation
Minus: Children may not want to disclose that this has occurred, or feel that the person is not a 'stranger'
References: Olson et al. 2007, "Entrapping the Innocent: Toward a Theory of Child Sexual Predators' Luring Communication"

Measures: Ability of child to list three ways to protect themselves online.
References: Keeping Children Safe Online

Measures: The Grooming Scale is composed of 13 items that are scored on a 4-point Likert scale from 1 (never or nothing) to 4 (always or a lot). The scale assesses situations of exhibitionism by personal desire or at the request of adults, and explicit grooming behaviors (e.g. “Have you had conversations over webcam with you or the other person being in underwear?”).
Plus: Well understood Likert style self-reporting measure
Minus: Same weaknesses as other self-reporting measures in terms of honest answers, particularly with grooming as highly intimate topic
References: Peris and Maganto 2018, 'Sexting, Sextorsión y grooming: identificación y prevención'

Measures: Sextortion is where the perpetrator threatens to release intimate images to family and the broader public unless the victim complies with their requests, often around obtaining more sexual imagery. Sextortion is distinct from online grooming, but also contains several overlaps. An evaluation might include metrics around sextortion as a way to grasp similar activities that participants may not consider to be online grooming.
Plus: May provide a more expansive understanding of the scope of sexual exploitation of children online
Minus: Slightly different dynamics from cybergrooming, so shouldn't be conflated with it directly
References: Kopecky 2017, 'Online blackmail of Czech children focused on so-called “sextortion”'

Indicator: Emotional and physical punishment by teachers
Measures: Measures the frequency of parents’ emotional and physical punishment, such as name calling, negative comparisons to others, and hitting or attempting to hit.
References: Moon, B., Hwang, H. W., & McCluskey, J. D. (2011). Causes of school bullying: Empirical test of a general theory of crime, differential association theory, and general strain theory. Crime & Delinquency, 57(6), 849-877.

Measures: There are several barriers preventing children from reporting. These include: Barriers from Within (e.g. internalized victim-blaming); Barriers in Relation to Others (e.g. power dynamics); and Barriers in Relation to the Social World (e.g. taboo of sexuality). To increase reporting, a programme might aim to measure and reduce these hurdles.
Plus: Established hurdles that inhibit children from reporting acts of sexual exploitation
Minus: Requires secondary indicators to measure the extent of these barriers (pre) and whether they have been reduced (post)
References: Collin-Vézina et al. 2015

Measures: Three risk factors for cybergrooming are being a girl, having a willingness to meet strangers offline, and being cyberbullied. Testing whether the latter two have decreased could be one way of evaluating a programme.
Plus: Widely cited factors associated with cybergrooming victimization
Minus: Requires secondary indicators to test (e.g. whether child has been cyberbullied)
References: Wachs, Wolf, and Pan 2012

Measures: Evaluative studies have asked whether participants (or their parents or caregivers) took action after a CSA awareness campaign, including 'talking to children', 'talking to friends/family', 'making an effort to be informed about CSA' or 'visiting a CSA education website'.
Plus: Concrete actions that would be reasonably straightforward to measure
Minus: These actions may raise awareness of CSA, but not result in behavioral change from child
References: Safer Scotland 2020, 'Child Sexual Exploitation Campaign Evaluation Report'

Measures: Some studies suggest a link between pornography consumption and harmful or aggressive sexual behaviors. The consumption of porn (frequency, duration, etc) across a platform might therefore function as a 'proxy' indicator for child sexual exploitation and the effectiveness of a programme.
Plus: Use of classifiers to detect porn on platforms well established
Minus: Proxy indicator that must be combined with others to get a more precise picture
References: McKibbin, Humphreys, and Hamilton 2017 'Young people who sexually abused reflect on preventing harmful sexual behavior', Taylor 2018 'Pornography as a Public Health Issue'

Indicator: Indecent Imagery across a Region or Country
Measures: One form of child sexual exploitation is through indecent imagery which is circulated. Some countries maintain databases where law enforcement has identified these images and recorded them over time. This provides one metric, albeit high level, for evaluating sexual exploitation at a regional or national level.
Plus: An easy to understand metric that is clearly criminal and exploitative
Minus: Very broad in encompassing a large population, causal factors difficult to determine
References: Bryce 2017, 'Exploitation through indecent images'

Indicator: Ability to Recognize and Deflect Grooming Language
Measures: While grooming is varied, there are certain tropes and language that reoccurs frequently. Studies have suggested roleplaying exercises that test the ability of participants to recognize and defend against these approaches.
Plus: Realistic in using phrases or strategies from 'real world' grooming scenarios
Minus: Major ethical issues, especially if participants are children
References: Egan et al. 2011, 'Perverted justice: A content analysis of the language used by offenders detected attempting to solicit children for sex'

Measures: Measure the number of cyberbullying or grooming instances reported across a particular platform, pre and post intervention, or even longer if possible.
Plus: Concrete statistic that can help "round out" other measures
Minus: Highly ambiguous, higher numbers could be due to more visible or accessible reporting mechanism, rather than increase in incidents
References: Facebook, Twitter, Riot Games 2014-2020

Indicator: Deceit and Bribery as Grooming Pathways
Measures: Deceit, bribery and nonsexual communication are three strategies used by perpetrators of sexual exploitation. Deceit often takes the form of stating a younger age and impersonating others. Bribery are gifts such as a webcam sent to the victim. Allowing users to report when this occurs and tracking these figures over time could provide an evaluative indicator.
Plus: Deceit and bribery clear 'actions' as opposed to ambiguous nonsexual communication
Minus: Requires reporting mechanisms, requires children to actively report
References: Gámez-Guadix et al. 2018, 'Persuasion strategies and sexual solicitations and interactions in online sexual grooming of adolescents'

Indicator: Questionnaire for Online Sexual Solicitation and Interaction With Adults (QOSSIA)
Measures: A questionnaire to assess the online sexual solicitation and interactions of minors with adults - how often, what was the encounter, what was their age and gender, and so on.
Plus: Well understood form of self-reporting, straightforward to implement
Minus: Same biases as other self-reporting measures, including embarassment
References: Gámez-Guadix, Santisteban, Alcazar 2018

Measures: Measures views, visits, number of messages shared, duration of session, and other statistics typically captured when deploying online marketing campaigns.
Plus: Concrete statistic that can demonstrate engagement and "round out" other measures
Minus: Tends to measure the popularity of the programme rather than providing indication of any behavioral change
References: Spears et al. 2016 "Safe and Well Online" project

Measures: Widely used measure for anxiety, including "social phobia, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder/agoraphobia, and other forms of anxiety."
References: Essau, CA; Muris, P; Ederer, EM (March 2002). "Reliability and validity of the Spence Children's Anxiety Scale and the Screen for Child Anxiety Related Emotional Disorders in German children". Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry. 33 (1): 1–18. doi:10.1016/S0005-7916(02)00005-8. PMID 12389796.

Measures: One of six indicators of strain suggested by Moon, Huang & McCluskey (2008), it "measures the extent of experience of verbal/physical conflict among family members as well as verbal/physical conflict between a respondent and parents".
References: Moon, B., Hwang, H. W., & McCluskey, J. D. (2011). Causes of school bullying: Empirical test of a general theory of crime, differential association theory, and general strain theory. Crime & Delinquency, 57(6), 849-877.

Indicator: Emotional and physical punishment by parents
Measures: Measures the frequency of parents' emotional and physical punishment, such as name calling, negative comparisons to others, and hitting or attempting to hit.
References: Moon, B., Hwang, H. W., & McCluskey, J. D. (2011). Causes of school bullying: Empirical test of a general theory of crime, differential association theory, and general strain theory. Crime & Delinquency, 57(6), 849-877.

Measures: Interview conducted with parent or teacher regarding ability of a child to protect themselves online.
References: Keeping Children Safe Online

Measures: Captures the degree to which young people feel stress related to studying for examinations and include "I feel a lot of stress about studying", "I am not satisfied with my grade", and "My parents stress studying too much."
References: Moon, B., Hwang, H. W., & McCluskey, J. D. (2011). Causes of school bullying: Empirical test of a general theory of crime, differential association theory, and general strain theory. Crime & Delinquency, 57(6), 849-877.

Measures: Adolescents who reported avoidant communication with their mother and loneliness had much higher risk of being cyberbullied. These can be assessed with the UCLA Loneliness Scale and the Parent-Child Communication scale. A programme might seek to improve these scores and therefore lessen the risk of cyberbullying victimization.
Plus: Brings in interpersonal and familial relationships to the understanding of cyberbullying victimization
Minus: Same weaknesses as other self-reporting measures in terms of requiring honest responses
References: Larannaga et al. 2016, 'Loneliness, parent-child communication and cyberbullying victimization among Spanish youths'

Measures: The first step in luring communication is gaining access to the victim. Measure the means and frequency of perpetrators gaining access (e.g. friend requests), either through self-reporting or platform analytics.
Plus: Narrow focus, crucial first step in online grooming pathways
Minus: Differentiating between giving access to perpetrators and giving access to friends/family is difficult
References: Olson et al. 2007, "Entrapping the Innocent: Toward a Theory of Child Sexual Predators' Luring Communication"

Measures: One study found that physical attractiveness and disinhibition led to increased sexting (both erotic and pornographic) and higher likelihood of adolescents being groomed. It suggested that education programs should thus stress cognitive and socio-emotional esteem on top of body self-esteem. Measuring and increasing this could be a productive evaluation indicator.
Plus: Holistic way of decreasing risk of online grooming
Minus: Self-esteem is a broad concept that may be difficult to accurately measure
References: Schoeps et al. 2020, 'Risk factor for being a victim of online grooming in adolescents'

Measures: A crucial step in luring communication is isolating the victim from friends, family, and support mechanisms. Measuring friend/family interactions over time, and ability to access support mechanisms (e.g. reporting) could provide a metric of isolation before and after a programme.
Plus: A sophisticated and more holistic metric that nicely supplements quantitative indicators
Minus: Tricky to define what isolation is and how it is measured
References: Olson et al. 2007, "Entrapping the Innocent: Toward a Theory of Child Sexual Predators' Luring Communication"
